title-group.article-title: A Technique for Measuring Interior Wind Rush Noise at the Clay Model Stage of Vehicle Design

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright Â© Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc., 1978

abstract.p: A technique has been developed to evaluate interior wind rush noise during wind tunnel tests of full-size clay models of vehicles. A small, box-like enclosure with acoustic characteristics made similar to those of a typical vehicle interior is inserted into the clay model behind an actual front sideglass. The wind rush noise coming through the sideglass is directly measured by microphones located within the enclosure. The technique can readily detect wind rush noise changes due to body modifications in the vicinity of the windshield-pillar. In addition, the wind tunnel results agree well with those found on-road.

ref.mixed-citation: W. R. Stapleford and G. W. Carr, "Aerodynamic Noise in Road Vehicles," Parts I and II, M.I.R.A. Reports, 1971/2 and 1972/6, November 1971 and May 1972.
"Wind Tunnel Benefits Aspen/Volare," Autoproducts Magazine, December 1975, p. 10.
I. D. Wilken, "Substitutes for Glass in Sound Transmission Tests Involving Auto- mobile Windows," submitted for publication in Noise Control Engineering.
Eckel Industries, Inc., "Anechoic Chambers," Engineering Data brochure published by Eckel Industries, Inc.
V. M. Viebrock and M. J. Crocker, "Miniature Anechoic Room Design," Journal of Sound and Vibration, 32(1), pp. 77-86, 1974.
